definition: names of the tunes to which 詞|词[ci2] poems are composed
word/statement/speech/lyrics/CL:組|组[zu3],個|个[ge4]/a form of lyric poetry, flourishing in the Song dynasty 宋朝|宋朝[Song4 chao2]/CL:首[shou3]

sentences.english: Some kinds of poems are very strict about rhyming.
sentences.chinese: 有些詞牌對詞韻的要求是相當嚴格的。

definition: regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
a genre of poetry, developed in the Tang Dynasty, characterized by its strict form
a pre-Tang Dynasty genre of poetry, relatively free in form, usually having four, five, six or seven characters per line
Ma Zhiyuan (c. 1250-1321), Yuan dynasty dramatist in the 雜劇|杂剧[za2 ju4] tradition of musical comedy, one of the Four Great Yuan Dramatists 元曲四大家[Yuan2 qu3 Si4 Da4 jia1]
poetic form consisting of four lines of five syllables, with rhymes on first, second and fourth line
antithesis (two lines of poetry matching in sense and sound)/to fight/to wage war
writing style in which the main subject is approached directly from the outset/opposite of 冒題|冒题[mao4 ti2]
to mark a text with dots and circles/to punctuate
verse form consisting of 8 lines of 7 syllables, with rhyme on alternate lines/abbr. to 七律
to pause at appropriate points in reading aloud unpunctuated writing/to punctuate
Yuan Haowen (1190-1257), famous poet Northern China during the Jin-Yuan transition
